The Hawaii State Senate unanimously approved Senate Bill 2046 Wednesday, which would prohibit the manufacture, sale, transfer, and possession of bump stocks and similar devices. The bump stock, which allows semi-automatic firearms to fire similarly to automatic weapons, was linked with the October 2017 mass shooting in Las Vegas. The Hawaii Rifle Association, a National Rifle Association affiliate, opposed the bill. President Harvey Gerwig wrote in testimony that the bill was vague, overreaching, and would "turn an innocent gun owner into a felon." According to the Honolulu Civil Beat, the bill did not receive much other opposition.
